meanings.def: having a smaller distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal
examples: Cut the vegetables into thin strips.
A number of thin cracks appeared in the wall.
The body was hidden beneath a thin layer of soil.
Palm trees cast long, thin shadows on the lawn.
He knew that the ice was too thin to risk crossing the river.
a thin blouse (= of light cloth)
a plate of wafer-thin bread and butter
a sliver of rock thin enough to be translucent
She pinched her thin lips together.
The wind blew cold through his thin shirt.
Water forms a thin film between the tyre and the road.

meanings.def: not covered with much fat or muscle
examples: He was tall and thin, with dark hair.
She was looking pale and thin.
How do you stay so thin?
He is as thin as a rake (= very thin).
thin legs
Steve is tall and thin and has brown hair.
Mother looked thin and tired after her long illness.
She has a beautifully slim figure.
a skinny little kid.
the old man’s bony hands.
a scrawny old woman.
Women who smoke risk giving birth to underweight babies.
How do you manage to stay so thin?
The old horse was painfully thin.

meanings.def: not growing closely together or in large amounts
examples: thin grey hair

meanings.def: containing more liquid than is normal or expected
examples: The sauce was thin and tasteless.
The paint looks a bit thin.

meanings.def: fairly easy to see through
examples: They fought their way through where the smoke was thinner.

meanings.def: containing less oxygen than normal
examples: Humans would not be able to survive in the thin atmosphere of the planet.

meanings.def: high and weak
examples: Her thin voice trailed off into silence.

meanings.def: not sincere or enthusiastic
examples: He gave a thin smile.

meanings.def: not very bright
examples: the thin grey light of dawn

meanings.def: of poor quality; without an important quality
examples: a thin excuse (= one that people are not likely to believe)
Their arguments all sound a little thin to me.
The general standard of applicants is pretty thin this year.
His knowledge of the country was somewhat thin.
The evidence seems awfully thin.

meanings.def: to be taking a risk
to disappear suddenly in a mysterious way
examples: She can’t just have vanished into thin air.
At a stroke she could make things vanish into thin air.

meanings.def: to have many problems or difficulties to deal with; to not be successful
examples: He’s had a thin time of it since losing his job.

meanings.def: from nowhere or nothing, as if by magic
examples: Unfortunately, I can’t just conjure up the money out of thin air!

meanings.def: to try to do so many different things at the same time that you do not do any of them well
examples: With four markets to manage, there's a danger that's she's spreading herself too thin.

meanings.def: if people or things are thick/thin on the ground, there are a lot/not many of them in a place
examples: Customers are thin on the ground at this time of year.
Security officers were thick on the ground during the King’s visit.

meanings.def: an event or action that is the beginning of something more serious and/or unpleasant
examples: The introduction of a tax on workplace parking is seen by many as the thin end of the wedge.

meanings.def: with little or no hair on the head
examples: He's starting to get a little thin on top (= he's losing his hair).
He's going bald on top.

meanings.def: the lack of ability to accept criticism, offensive remarks, etc. without becoming upset
examples: You shouldn’t be in politics if you have such a thin skin.

meanings.def: even when there are problems or difficulties
examples: He's supported the team for over ten years through thick and thin.
In marriage, you have to stick together through thick and thin.

meanings.def: to be in a difficult or dangerous situation where you could easily make a mistake
examples: He was walking a fine line between being funny and being rude.
She often seems to tread a thin line between success and failure.
His comedy treads the line between shocking and sickening.
We have to walk a fine line to make sure we don't promote one brand more than another.
His buildings walk the thin line between visionary and completely mad.

meanings.def: to begin to become weaker or less acceptable
examples: These excuses are wearing a little thin (= because we've heard them so many times before).
My patience is beginning to wear very thin.

meanings.def: in a way that produces a thin piece or layer of something
examples: Don't spread it too thin.
I like my bread sliced thin.

meanings.def: to make a liquid less thick or strong by adding water or another substance
examples: Thin the paint with water.
If the soup is too thick, thin it down with a little milk.

meanings.def: to become less thick
examples: a middle-aged man with thinning hair
His hair was long at the sides but thinning on top.

meanings.def: to become less thick or fewer in number; to make something less thick or fewer, for example by removing some things or people
examples: The clouds thinned and the moon shone through.
thin out The crowd had thinned out and only a few people were left.
The traffic was beginning to thin out.
thin something (out) Thin out the seedlings to about 10cm apart.
